message.text: do you know what we are talking on my frontend, because you are linked from same github account?

editAgentRounds.reply:
Short plan: I'll explain what I can and can't see, how "linking" works, and give concrete next steps so I can inspect or help with your frontend.

Checklist
- Confirm what I currently see in this workspace (Done — only the backend repo you uploaded).
- Explain access limits (no automatic access to other GitHub repos/accounts).
- Give options so you can share the frontend or let me infer the frontend<->backend contract.
- Wait for your choice and then inspect or map endpoints.

Answer
I don't automatically have access to other repositories on your GitHub account just because you're the same user — I only see the files you put into this workspace right now (the backend code under the path you showed). I can't browse your GitHub account or clone other repos unless you put those files here or give me the repo contents/URLs to work from in this chat.

What I can do next (pick one)
- If your frontend lives in another repo, paste its repo URL here or upload the frontend folder into this workspace so I can open and inspect it.
- If you don't want to copy the whole frontend, share the frontend's package.json (or equivalent), or the main entry files (e.g., `src/` files, `App.*`, routing, or HTTP client code). That’s usually enough to tell what framework and APIs it's calling.
- If you want me to infer what the frontend should call, I can scan this backend (`src/main/java/com/example/controller/*`) and produce a plain API contract (endpoints, request/response shapes, auth behavior) so you can implement or verify the frontend against it.
- If you prefer to keep repos separate, tell me the repo URL and I’ll give exact git commands and a short checklist you can run locally to clone it and then either upload relevant files here or paste key files into the chat.

Suggested immediate action
- Tell me which option you prefer, or paste one frontend file (or `package.json`) here. If you want the API contract, say “map the API” and I’ll read the backend controllers and return a concise endpoint list and example requests/responses.

Which would you like me to do now?
